reviews.review_text: This game has more nukes than Fallout

I grew up playing Total Annihilation back in 1998 and i still find myself still hopping back on every now and then. Supreme Commander 1 was a true successor to my beloved TA, and it still is. I found a new love. A year or 2 later, Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance came out, which in my opinion is the definitive edition. The scale of Supreme Commander 1 is grand. I'm a huge RTS fan and supreme commander 1 has to by my number 1 favorite RTS game of all time, aside from its predecessor Total Annihilation of course. These 2 games have taken away a good portion of my life.  Now on to Supreme Commander 2..... ummmm..... I'm heartbroken. I've forced myself to play it a few times but i honestly just cant take it. Its horrible. SupCom2 does not have the same gameplay as SupCom1. The scale of SupCom 2 is too dumbed down. There is no sense of grand scale in this game. The maps are unsatisfyingly too small. The unit cap is also extremely low. And the unit designs are crap. This game is just sad and ruins the Supreme Commander name  For those of you who have never played SupCom1, then you might think that this is a good/decent game. I dont blame you.  As a fan of Total Annihilation and Supreme Commander, please hear me out...  DO NOT BUY THIS GAME! (I mean you can if you want. I'll just pity you). Go Purchase SUPREME COMMANDER: FORGED ALLIANCE!

As a fan of the original Total Annihilation series I liked what the old Cave Dog group did, Supreme Commander and Forged Alliance were good enough, but Sup Com 2 does not do the franchise justice at all. It is a very dumbed down version which replaces many of the original’s mechanics with research grinding rather then building up bases and getting more advanced units. Basic units are just that, basic they are very boring and very small versus the levels and other units, while you can upgrade them with various research items to make them more effective it does a very poor job at replacing the 3+1 unit tier levels from the previous games. With this game now more then ever you rely heavily on the experimental units rather then building up a force of mixed units of various tiers with maybe one or two X units in the mix.  The main campaign does a good enough job at some kind of a story and MOST of the missions are gradual in their difficulty and challenge. However that difficulty spikes abnormally high when you reach the final 4 to 6 missions of the Cybran and you will fail multiple times before you figure out what the developers wanted you to do.   The skirmish AI and the AI in general tends to cheat and does so pretty obviously, getting clear stat, research speed, mass and energy boasts right off the bat, even on normal difficulty, which is a shame because I always enjoyed the TA/SC skirmish games.   I had shied away from buying this game when it came out after hearing reviews that it was a very basic and stripped version designed for mostly console play so I avoided it until 2013’s Christmas sale. I am glad I did because as much as I really wanted enjoy this game and get just as much play out of it as I did with Sup Com/FA and Total Annihilation it would seem that that is not the case. This will be one of the few games that I have purchased that will not last long on my hard drive, possibly to make room for something more worth while.  If you really want to continue to the story of Sup Com and FA, then by all means buy it when it’s on sale again, but do NOT buy this if you were a fan of TA or SC/FA. This honestly makes me worry about what Planetary Annihilation will be like which I hope will not be the case.
Awesome stratergy game, however i think that SupComFA was better, and it had alot more units. This game needs more naval forces. Other thank thant its Amazing!

Did you like Supreme Commander (and Total Annihilation)?  Then there is nothing for you here. They patched out *some* of the Starcraftisms since the demo, but it's still faster, smaller, and shallower, with tons of weird regressions. Experimentals aren't, unit variety is slashed, nukes are like hand grenades, there are interface regressions everywhere.  Oh, and this is just multiplayer. We thought some variety might at least be enough of a welcome novelty from FA games to overlook its flaws, but it just isn't. The singleplayer, meanwhile, is absolutely godawful, with writing that would embarrass a direct-to-TV disaster movie.  It doesn't matter how cheap it is in a sale, this isn't of the TA lineage in any meaningful way, and Squeenix do not deserve your wallet change for ripping the heart out of the game and feeding it to the Zerg.

I had great hopes for this game back when it was announced. It had big shoes to fill considering how excellent Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance was. However, everytime I play this game it makes me want to go back and play Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance (SC:FA) instead.   Pros: -Some cool experimental units -Some good art design -The level design is engaging -Characters are more fleshed out compared to previous ones  Cons: -Everything has been dumbed down -Economy has completely changed from the SC exp: can't spend energy and mass at a deficit -Interface is worse than SC:FA -Gone are the grand battles involving 250+ units -Much smaller scale than SC:FA -Tier system is gone and replaced with research -Unit variety -Maps don't come close to the size of a 64x64 SC:FA map -Cybran ACU looks awful  GPG Changed most of what made the previous SC games so great. The complexity and scale are defining characteristics of the series. Lacking these characteristics, the game falls flat. If a Supcom 3 is ever made it needs to go back to Supcom 1 and FA for influence not Supcom 2. I don't recommend this game if you are a fan of SC: FA. IF you haven't played SC:FA you need to forget this game and get go get SC:FA

Basicly a dumbed down version of the original. Interestingly though, it has become a different flavour of the same thing, but they both taste equally good. The game is simple and that makes it interesting, everything is flat and rather straightforward but it works.  It suffers from all the flaws the original has. Poor AI, when you can get experimentals .. spam the crap out of them, missions that are only difficult (if at all) for the first 10-ish minutes, etc. However the game plays quite nicelly, it has cheating AI's in skirmish/MP and because of the 'flatness' you do not have to reserve 2+ hours to take down a cheating AI in skirmish or do a single campaign mission. Compared to the original, with 5 (or 6?) mission, it actually has 15 though. That does offer some more variaty in the missions but the overall time you spend on the campaign wont be much longer than you spend doing the campaign in the original.

This game quickly became one of if not my favorites after a friend bought it for me. All three factions are different and unique much like their units. Every map is well designed, the game is gorgeous (especially the robots id take one out for a date), you want the game to lag so you can watch the epic end game battle with all of your forces versus the enemies in slow motion. The base building is amazing, and it's sad to see a base go after the games over. SupCom2 is a fun game which removes some of the tedious aspects from the first SupCom game (e.g. managing fuel for aerial units). Some people see it as a dumbing down, but I think it's a streamlined game which gives you more of what I want.   It's long in the tooth now, but I'm happy to have bought it. It's also terrific for lan parties. And as it's old, you won't run into problems having to download GBs of updates when you arrive at the party. :)

Well I have many hours in this game and prob just as many in the first game. First off SC2 was a trade off in scale to be able to run on the xbox 360 (which is actually a good game if your looking for a good strategy for your console). But it still has more scale than many other popular RTS games. The game is far less unit managament and less unit upgrade focused. You basically pick your attack path at the beginning and off you go, changing from your direction in the game is a bit hard to pull off but with a good teammate it can be done. The game has great graphics, but unfortunetly it can't take advantage of our awesome new multi-core CPU's we have today, infact it really only uses 1 core and about 20% of a 2nd if you have it, for example the game ran as fast on my 4.2ghz pentium 4 extreme edition as it did on my Q6600 when I got the game years ago. Gas Powered games is gone now, but just before they were bought up they released a new AI patch which really helped with a lot of the stupidy the AI had, the AI was already challenging but i quickly found a lot of tactics no longer worked against certain levels of enemies. Faction balance is terrible in the standard game, imo of course, but once you add the DLC the game gets a whole new persective, every faction can now push there attacks in all 4 major ways (naval, air, land, artillery) except Aion who have no artillery. At the current price point you would be a fool to not pick up the game and the DLC they are completly worth it. Single player I still need to finish, I have always been terrible about finishing single player in RTS games though :) If your playing a large multiplayer match or want to get into multiplayer make sure to get some friends going(you use steam to invite into games), and make sure who ever has the most powerful system hosts the game.

TL;DR: I'll put the tldr segment first because of the way they format the text: Supreme Commander 2 is a basic RTS that did not hold on to what it had in the first two games of the franchise. If you have not played the first games and are just looking for a nice looking RTS, then this is your game.   I have played Supreme Commander since the original was released back in 2007, I loved that game and it brought many new features to the RTS scene that have now become pretty much standard (ex: “strategic zoom”). After the pretty much utter failure of Forged Alliance, I was pretty surprised to see a sequel to a game whose first installment was pretty good, but had lost grasp on its fans by making a spin off and releasing it as a full game at full price when it really should have been an expansion or DLC. The First two games: Supreme Commander and Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance, were both produced by THQ, developed by Gas Powered Games and to quote from the boxes “An Arts From [designed by] Christ Taylor”. These games had many mechanics that separated from other RTSs that were out that the time. The games had a focus on large unit management (I’m talking 1000+ units, none of that 200 max unit stuff you see in other games) to dominate the battlefield, players also had to use the terrain to their advantage to flank their enemies.   The resource management system that was in place in the first titles was also very different from other games at the time. Instead of having a set amount of resource in your position and you’re only able to build units with that set amount (if that makes any sense), SC and SCFA both had a resource rate system. This system would allow you to build as many units as you wanted, just production would slow down if you did not have a high enough rates of resources coming in, creating some pretty interesting situations when you realize that one of you Mass Extractors had been removed and you wonder why you’re not building as fast.   Units in the first two games were handled by a tier system. When you could afford to spend some time and had some extra resource coming in you could choose to upgrade up to two higher (because you start on tier one) tiers unlocking new units and engineers to build. When you obtain enough tier three engineers (for sake of practicality) you could build some pretty power game ender units called Experimental Units. These beasts included things such as a mobile factory that could build almost anything almost instantly and was pretty much indestructible, to gigantic humanoid robots that would shoot laser beams from their eyes. You could also build a unit called a Support Command Units, which were smaller less functional versions of the main Armored Command Units (which is what you play as), pretty much they make great suicidal units.   Now enough about the first to games in the franchise, let’s talk about Supreme Commander 2 (the third game of the series). You may be wondering why I spent all that time talking about the first games in the series; well it’s because they changed all that (well most of it). Publication of Supreme Commander 2 was transferred over to Square Enix, but was still developed by Gas Powered Games. The seconded game had more of a focus on small group combat rather than large scale unit combat like in the first game. The map design was also drastically different with even more of a requirement on terrain use. This wasn’t really a bad thing; the new maps were interesting and helped to balance the support between each kind of unit (land, air, sea). However one of the biggest flaws with in the game was with the units. They scrapped the tier system that was present in the first game for tech tree system. Gone are the days were you could build cheap factories that would pump out meat shields and cheap scouts. With this new tree system the placed in a resource, research points, along with the original two, Mass, and Energy. These points could be farmed or gained just from passing time, and then spent in the tree. Now some of these upgrades are pretty interesting, you can detach the control module of the AUC to make a quick escape and then make a bad-♥♥♥ comeback; but still the heavy focus on the system felt to simplify what made the first games unique and challenging; now all your factories have access two those high power units, and you no longer have to micromanage them. But by far the worst change that they made was to the resource system. They went from an “interest” based income system as I described before, to the standard “bank” system that is present in other RTSs such as Star Craft. This hurt the game, slowing the pacing down from all out action which made the first game amazing fun, to a waiting game to see who can farm the most and get Experimental Units first.   In the end Supreme Commander 2 is a decent strategy game, but that’s all it is. GPG did not stick to what made the first two games so different, high pacing action with ridiculous unit counts and lots of explosions. The maps are interesting enough to keep games exciting for the first few rounds, and the visuals are fantastic even for a three year old game. However I still can’t help but feel hurt that this cult favorite that really was the benchmark for RTSs (both visually and mechanically) at the time it was released has been watered down to please a wider demographic. Also I feel that I should note that it was released a few weeks before Star Craft 2 so that didn’t help with sales. In all I would recommend the first two games over this one: Supreme Commander, and Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance, if you want a unique RTS experience and don’t already own them. If you want a beautiful RTS with unique units but really basic mechanics then go right ahead and pick up Supreme Commander 2.

After playing over 100 hours i can say this. If you aren't a strategy genius but really want to try a Supreme Commander game, this is the one. Simple resource system, simple base building. I would also recommend you get Supreme Commander 1 or Forged Alliances, the original brings a challenge even for me! (I've been playing games like this for 6 years.)   PROS

Looking for some large-scale real-time warfare strategy? Check this game out. While not so large and comprehensive as first Supreme Commander (and Supreme Commander - Forged Alliance), it's still the king of RTSes and puts Starcraft 2 to its knees. Punching the enemy with 250 units or effectively using multi-monitor setups? Not many games can give you that, and SupCom 2 is the one of them. Or maybe you loved 'Total Annihilation'? You should like Supreme Commander 2 too.

Not bad, but it's definitely not the first game. In the first game and Forged Alliance the building tier and unit tier system was so much more advance and complex, in this game it just feels too dumbed down for my liking and I don't get the same satisfaction for winning than when I did in the first game. Campaign is fairly decent but again a huge let down compared to the first game.

Now, before I explain why I don't reccommend this, let me establish that this is, indeed, a VERY fun game. Its just dissappointing, compared to the previous SupCom games. My biggest issue, is how useless shields are. They cover next to nothing, in SupCom:FA, you could cover your entire base with 3 or 4 heavy shield generators. Now, in a DLC, you can get an experimental shield generator, but that's the DLC, and Im not talking about the DLC, Im talking about the game. Another issue I have with this, is the border markers, PDs range, shields range, etc. Its a thick ring, that doesnt give you a very precise-feeling measurement. I much prefer Supreme Commander's thin ring, it feels so much better. Also, they obliterated some of my favorite experimentals, namely the FatBoy. That thing was a beast, heavy shield gen, long range cannons, unit production capabilities. Now its just a big bloody tank. I love this game. But I would advise against buying it, go and buy the fist Supreme Commander, or Forged Alliance.

What to say about this game. First visually it looks great, even several years after the release it looks great. Gameplay wise its in shambles. User interface and function is terrible. Im not an expert at the so called 4x strategy games, part of this issue comes from really poorly designed user interfaces. Instead of providing options to manage base building on the fly you are required to bounce back and forth with your units. Couple that with an AI that can do that on the fly, makes this very frustrating. Unit building is slow and you cant tell if something is building or not, the contruction should be individual to each building unit and not ordered by unit, so it makes unit construction slow and painful since most times when i should be seeing a massive group of units waiting for me to select, instead all i see is one and the next one is in a queue waiting because the unit from a different pool is currently be produced and this is on top of a possitive resource system with excess resources waiting. This is on top of the typical AI crap that is in every game, the AI will always have available the exact unit to counter my units and have almost immediate access to replacement units. The single player game is a choir after the first two missions because of this.
Still a GREAT FUN game

If you're looking for Supreme Commander mark 2, you're looking in the wrong place.  Supreme Commander was a great if under-appreciated RTS. It was one of the first to introduce various sized units that could literally walk over their smaller brethren. It had an engaging storyline and was generally an interesting and worthwhile game.  This is not.  Supreme Commander 2 is a screensaver that happens to use the same graphics. Gone are the RTS elements that you have come to expect, and they've been replace with something more akin to a strategic mapping program. Your focus is less on building, battling and overcoming, and more on minutia.  Everything about this game reeks of desperation by the developers. The odor of their greedy profit-mongering can be felt in every underdeveloped, subpar, mediocre moment of this game. It is patently obvious that there was little to no real effort put into this game, with the sole focus being to churn out discs in a short time frame and sell them to fans.  To put this in Ian Malcolm terms they wanted to 'patent it, package it, and slap it on a plastic lunch box. Now you want to sell it. You were so busy wondering if you could, you never stopped and asked yourselves if you should'
great game love the multiplayer

Think of an RTS as a rhythm game. It's all about finding a decent rhythm in unit production, to research, to micro and macro with your entire army. You must maintain your rhythm while also disrupting your opponent's. I bought this game during the Winter sale for $3.24. This game isn't even worth THAT.  Here's where this game's problem comes in: this game makes no ♥♥♥♥ing sense. The tutorial was written by ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ seven year olds who don't the understand the basic concept of what makes an RTS an RTS. The game's rhythm is all place, it feels like Beethoven did a line of cocaine on his piano and then bashed his face on the piano keys. If my friends have to tell me to not play the Tutorial and just experience the mechanics on their own to like this game, only for me to bash my keyboard in blind fury at the stupidity of the mechanics, things aren't boding well.  This is coming from a person who plays RTS games all the time. I have over 6000 hours on games like Total Annihilation Kingdoms (June 25, 1999), War of the Ring (November 4 2003), StarCraft (March 31, 1998) and StarCraft 2 (July 27, 2010) and WarCraft 3 (July 3, 2002). Mind you, StarCraft 2 came out THE SAME YEAR as this game. It took me FOUR MINUTES to understand the components of StarCraft 1 and how to play it, and even less time to understand StarCraft 2. I've played for almost over an hour and STILL don't understand what makes this game tick.  Each and every one of the games I just spoke of above have superiority in all aspects, leagues above this game. Game feel, mechanics, art design, story, ease of accessibilty, easy to understand, and gameplay. I have not played any of the other Supreme Commander games, but from the looks of it, not only does this game ♥♥♥♥ on its predecessors, but on Strategy games as a whole.  Do not buy this game.  Refunded. I want my ♥♥♥♥ing $3.24 back. No words will be able to express exactly how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ I am on this game. This game caused me to go on a freaking rage rant on the history of Strategy games for around two hours with my friends being forced to smile and nod.

This game stinks compared to supreme command 1 and forged alliance. They took everything that made those two unique to the rts genre and threw it out the window. I don't even get how supcom2 is supposed to work.  First all the resources became like static. Gone is the balance of energy and metals in vs spent. You can't upgrade your collectors anymore. So basically each level you are completely limited on resources. Then they severly limited the number of units you can build. All the maps are smaller. So you end up just building the biggest units you can. And then they drastically reduced the number of units. No more countering units and build specific strike groups of mixed types. And now units have upgrades instead of different level bases. So you just spam upgrades, build as much research facilities as you can and then max everything. All strategic depth, rushing vs building, what to build, what stuff to use, it's all gone.  I didn't even finish it cus it's so bland. And even if you didn't play supcom1, it's still a very dull rts game. Just go get supcom1, please. Don't waste your time here.

TL:DR If you like RTS games go buy Supreme Commander Forged Alliance. First things first: If you are a fan of Total Annihilation and/or Supreme Commander 1 / Forged Alliance. This game is not what you are looking for. To me it felt like the dumbed-down version of Supreme Commander FA. (which is actually quite a nice catch for some)  If you are however someone that likes StarCraft or similar strategy games and are looking for something a bit larger. This is a nice start. (and if you like it, look up the older supcom1/FA and give those a spin)  The research system is a nice deviation from previous strategy games, it reminds of a system used in C&C generals although much more options.   Overall, the game runs smooth, the campaign story is quite decent.   However, there is just one thing really wrong with this game.  Resource management and build queues don't line up good. You are unaware if you have resource-issues. The resource management claims you have a postive flow of resources, while your builders are waiting in queue to build something. That should somehow be visible.  (on the bright side, I know understand why StarCraft has a limited build queue :) This problem is not a game-breaker per se, however, it can be a frustrating point from time to time.   Overall: It's a good game. Worth a shot if you can get it cheap.

I started this series with Supreme Commander and then moved on to Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance. I've played thousands of fun and amazing hours of the first two games and it only took me a few hours to find the horrible flaws in this one.  This game is nothing like either of the first two games in function or in spirit . It is an all around disappointment, with so many things changed for the worse. For example, build queues beyond your current resources (the ability to plan ahead) are gone. Units have been simplified and unit numbers reduced. The overall game has taken on the per-game-leveling mechanics as those seen in the Battle for Middle-earth II and Command and Conquer: Generals RTS games. Map sizes have been greatly reduced and the graphics are terrible: the units look like fisher price toys.  Basically, if you've never played the series, this game will be overly difficult to learn for what you get back from it and if you're a huge fan, like me, you'll absolutely hate the changes they've made.  One reviewer said something like 'Chris Taylor has created a game that is, simultaneously, too simple for experienced players and too complicated for new ones'. That about sums it up. This one should be nominated for 'The Worst Sequel Ever' award.

The maps are smaller than in Supreme Commander 1 but you can reach the big battles quicker.  The game overall feels more streamlined. Skirmish matches last around 30 to 45 minutes as opposed to Supreme Commander 1 where matches could take 2 to 3 hours.  I also recommend the DLC.

A truly entertaining and addictive RTS. The feeling of power and dominance is undeniable as you control hundreds upon hundreds of units at once, all of which are ready to do your will and vanquish your enemy. The campaign is slightly tedious but the depth and immersion of the storyline makes it well worth the few hours. Be warned, however, hardcore fans of the first Supreme Commander will find a completely different experience much less focused on the city building and micromanagement side of RTS and geared more towards how well players can manage easily obtained resources to build massive armies. This as a result has led to the second major issue with this game; a minuscule and virtually non-existent online community. Online multiplayer in Supreme Commander 2 is one of the best RTS experiences that can be had but you will find very few games, most of which populated by very good players. It's really simple. If you've played/own SC1 and/or FA, this game will probably disappoint you. In general, lots of options have been taken out which were present in the predecessors, including diversity and lots of tactical features, especially the latter being very important aspect of RTS genre.  However, this has been happening with most of (RTS, but also others as well) games recently. This game fits into this new category of 'next-gen' games. The UI and Graphics have been updated (although in SC2 it isn't as fake flashy as in other new games), so it appeals to new and probably young players (who otherwise lose their attention if they aren't surprised in the first few seconds of seeing a new game, and the very first thing you see in a game is how it looks like). Also, it has been simplified a lot (or, I think it was both partly, it wasn't really finished yet), but that again can have its positive effects, like new players get into it faster and you can convince friends to play it easier.  So for situations where you've got some time for a long battle, together with other RTS-dedicated friends, SC1 and FA fits better. However, especially if you haven't (yet) played the previous ones in the series, this game can really be awesome and fun to play. The largest maps in the game, while far from the size of SC1's and FA's 81x81km games where you really wish you had some Homeworld hyperspace modules, they still give some lengthy plays and tactical options. The smaller maps are good for quick plays, when you don't have that much time. You've still got control of exlusions of what can't be built in Skirmish/MP and the game can be modded quite easily (although not many mods are made), so for some casual battles you can change things slightly (like I find it relaxing to sometimes play without nukes and/or air units). Also, some mods are actually quite good, and some bring back some SC1/FA features.  So to conclude, if you want lots of tactics, slow(er) gameplay, grand scale and planning, you'll probably like SC1 and FA better. However, if you want some quick matches, easier play/calmer learning curve, or want some friends to join you quickly who might not be into RTS games that much, SC2 is a quite nice game to play. I'd certainly recommend buying it in a sale, it really is worth the price when it's reduced like that. Oh, and don't forget to buy the Infinite War DLC, it is a must for the game!

Dont play this game. Go get Supreme Commander 1 Forged alliance and then install the blackops and the Total Mayhem mods.  Supreme Commander 2 was actually a game that digressed instead of progressed. They ruined it with part 2.   On the other hand, Supreme Commander Forged alliance has better graphics, more units, more strategy... just way better. you would think that a part 2 would be better than a part 1 but that is not the case with this series.   The story modes in all of these games are really bad.. it is the skirmishes that really stand out. These games all contain way less micro and much more macro.

I even tried with the Revamp mod. While it added a few new things, this game is still horrible.   My main gripes are: 1. You can't select multiple engineers to build a structure (almost every other RTS on the planet allows this) , you have to select only one 2. You can't have engineers/ACU assist in the building of anything. 3. You can't even start to build something unless you have 100% of the resources in your stockpile (If I want to play StarCraft, I will go play StarCraft). Chris Taylor's RTS games used to stand out, in that, you could start to build something as your resources came in. Not so in this one. 4. Units/structures are not tech upgradable like in SupCom and FA. Instead, teching up forces you to use an abitrary and very clunky tech tree making the game more about earning tech points than trying to strategically and tactically upgrade when possible. (If I want to play Civ, I will just go and play Civ).  All in all, the is one of the worst RTS games I have ever played which is a shame because I am normally in awe of Chris Taylor's RTS's. Play Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance instead, it is WORLDS better.   I simply can't figure out how this got the reviews that it did.

I really wanted to love this game so much, but it has lost the epic feel that playing Supreme Commander Forged Alliances gave! Tiny maps and utter defacing of factions has pulled the heart and soul out of it for me. That said, it does have some appealing features.  Pros: - The tech tree is a nice touch. Forcing commanders to favour certain tactics because of technological limitations adds a new edge to the game that its older brothers lacked. - The commander now feels alike a COMMANDER! More tools and tricks help to really make you feel like you are a presence on the battle field. I especialy like the 'escape pod' feature for getting out of a squeeze and for pure opponent frustration! - I really loved the DLC - Great to bring the infamous Spider Monkey back out and onto the field!   Cons: - The scale of the maps has been reduced massively, making the battlefields feel comparatively tiny. - The units have gone from chatoic and fun to just plain childish (Cybranasaurus?! Its like Jurassic World in here!) And what on earth is going on with the giant Aeon snail? - What happened to the silver fleet of the Aeon?! The massive unstoppable tide of the old world has been replaced with a fleet of cruddy hovercraft! Navel warfare just doesnt play like it used to :( - Whilst alot of the new units are really good, they look like they have been coloured in by a four year old. Pastoral and pastey.  Super Nasty Con: I hate the campaign.... really soppy and layerless. I miss the old Dr. Brakeman, I miss the terrifying Aeon and I miss the U-S of 'UEF' - A!

This is a perfectly decent RTS. Compared to the first Supreme Commander game, this has a lot more experimental units that are much easier to build, so if you like giant robot battles, this is your game. And most of the stategic depth of the game comes from the varying abilities of the experimentals available to each faction. That being said, the basic units have very little variation from faction to faction, and cover far fewer roles than the first game, thus leaving you with fewer strategic options than before. Also, the Aeon no longer have naval units, and the Seraphim from Forged Alliance do not return in this sequel. So, while this is a perfectly decent game, and adds some interesting new experimental units to the series, Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is a better strategy game in general.
